# Constantinople

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the historical city from 330 to 1453. For its
predecessor in Greek and early Roman times, see [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium
"Byzantium"). For Constantinople during the Ottoman era and the modern city,
see [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"). For other uses, see [Constantinople
(disambiguation)](/wiki/Constantinople_\(disambiguation\) "Constantinople
\(disambiguation\)").

**Constantinople** ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"):
Κωνσταντινούπολις _Konstantinoúpolis_ or Κωνσταντινούπολη _Konstantinoúpoli_ ;
[Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): _Constantinopolis_ ; [Ottoman
Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language "Ottoman Turkish language"):
قسطنطینية‎, translit.  _Ḳosṭanṭīnīye_) was the [capital
city](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") of the [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire
"Roman Empire")/[Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire")
(330–1204 and 1261–1453), and also of the brief [Latin](/wiki/Latin_Empire
"Latin Empire") (1204–1261), and the later [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire
"Ottoman Empire") (1453–1923) empires. It was reinaugurated in 324 AD from
ancient [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium") as the new capital of the
Roman Empire by Emperor [Constantine the Great](/wiki/Constantine_the_Great
"Constantine the Great"), after whom it was named, and dedicated on 11 May 330
AD.[5]

From the mid-5th century to the early 13th century, Constantinople was the
largest and wealthiest city in Europe[6] and it was instrumental in the
advancement of Christianity during Roman and Byzantine times as the home of
the [Ecumenical Patriarch of
Constantinople](/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical
Patriarch of Constantinople") and as the guardian of Christendom's holiest
relics such as the [Crown of Thorns](/wiki/Crown_of_thorns "Crown of thorns")
and the [True Cross](/wiki/True_Cross "True Cross"). After the final loss of
its provinces in the early 15th century, the Byzantine Empire was reduced to
just Constantinople and its environs, along with [Morea](/wiki/Morea "Morea")
in Greece, and the city [eventually fell](/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople "Fall
of Constantinople") to the Ottomans after a month-long siege in 1453.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Bizansist_touchup.jpg/300px-
Bizansist_touchup.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bizansist_touchup.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bizansist_touchup.jpg "Enlarge")

Aerial view of Byzantine Constantinople and the Propontis (Sea of Marmara)

Constantinople was famed for its massive and complex defences. Although
besieged on numerous occasions by various peoples, the defences of
Constantinople proved invulnerable for nearly nine hundred years before the
city was taken in 1204 by the Crusader armies of the [Fourth
Crusade](/wiki/Fourth_Crusade "Fourth Crusade"), and after it was liberated in
1261 by the Byzantine Emperor [Michael VIII
Palaiologos](/wiki/Michael_VIII_Palaiologos "Michael VIII Palaiologos"), a
second and final time in 1453 when it was conquered by the Ottoman
[Sultan](/wiki/Sultan "Sultan") [Mehmed II](/wiki/Mehmed_II "Mehmed II"). The
first wall of the city was erected by [Constantine I](/wiki/Constantine_I
"Constantine I"), and surrounded the city on both land and sea fronts. Later,
in the 5th century, the [Praetorian Prefect](/wiki/Praetorian_prefect
"Praetorian prefect") [Anthemius](/wiki/Anthemius_\(praetorian_prefect\)
"Anthemius \(praetorian prefect\)") under the child emperor [Theodosius
II](/wiki/Theodosius_II "Theodosius II") undertook the construction of the
[Theodosian Walls](/wiki/Theodosian_Walls "Theodosian Walls"), which consisted
of a double wall lying about 2 km (1.2 miles) to the west of the first wall
and a moat with palisades in front.[7] This formidable complex of defences was
one of the most sophisticated of
[Antiquity](/w/index.php?title=Classical_antiquity.&action=edit&redlink=1
"Classical antiquity. \(page does not exist\)"). The city was built
intentionally to rival Rome, and it was claimed that several elevations within
its walls matched the 'seven hills' of Rome. Because it was located between
the [Golden Horn](/wiki/Golden_Horn "Golden Horn") and the [Sea of
Marmara](/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara "Sea of Marmara") the land area that needed
defensive walls was reduced, and this helped it to present an impregnable
fortress enclosing magnificent palaces, domes, and towers, the result of the
prosperity that was engendered by its being the gateway between two
[continents](/wiki/Continent "Continent") (Europe and Asia) and two seas (the
Mediterranean and the Black Sea).

The city was also famed for its architectural masterpieces, such as the [Greek
Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") cathedral
of [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"), which served as the seat
of the [Ecumenical
Patriarchate](/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical
Patriarchate of Constantinople"), the sacred [Imperial
Palace](/wiki/Great_Palace_of_Constantinople "Great Palace of Constantinople")
where the Emperors lived, the [Galata Tower](/wiki/Galata_Tower "Galata
Tower"), the [Hippodrome](/wiki/Hippodrome_of_Constantinople "Hippodrome of
Constantinople"), the [Golden Gate](/wiki/Golden_Gate_\(Constantinople\)
"Golden Gate \(Constantinople\)") of the Land Walls, and the opulent
aristocratic palaces lining the arcaded avenues and squares. The [University
of Constantinople](/wiki/University_of_Constantinople "University of
Constantinople") was founded in the fifth century and contained numerous
artistic and literary treasures before it was sacked in 1204 and 1453,[8]
including its vast [Imperial Library](/wiki/Imperial_Library_of_Constantinople
"Imperial Library of Constantinople") which contained the remnants of the
[Library of Alexandria](/wiki/Library_of_Alexandria "Library of Alexandria")
and had over 100,000 volumes of ancient texts.[9]

Constantinople never truly recovered from the devastation of the Fourth
Crusade and the decades of misrule by the Latins. Although the city partially
recovered in the early years after the restoration under the
[Palaiologos](/wiki/Palaiologos "Palaiologos") dynasty, the advent of the
Ottomans and the subsequent loss of the Imperial territories until it became
an enclave inside the fledgling Ottoman Empire rendered the city severely
depopulated when it fell to the Ottoman Turks,[10] whereafter it replaced
[Edirne](/wiki/Edirne "Edirne") (Adrianople) as the new capital of the Ottoman
Empire.[11]

## Names[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Names")]

### Before
Constantinople[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Before Constantinople")]

According to [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder") in his
_[Natural History](/wiki/Natural_History_\(Pliny\) "Natural History
\(Pliny\)")_ , the first known name of a settlement on the site of
Constantinople was _Lygos,_[12] a settlement of likely Thracian origin founded
between the 13th and 11th century BC.[13] The site, according to the founding
myth of the city, was abandoned by the time Greek settlers from the city-state
of [Megara](/wiki/Megara "Megara") founded _[Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium
"Byzantium")_ ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Βυζάντιον,
_Byzántion_) in around 657 BC,[14] across from the town of
[Chalcedon](/wiki/Chalcedon "Chalcedon") on the Asiatic side of the Bosphorus.

The origins of the name of _[Byzantion](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium")_ , more
commonly known by the later Latin _Byzantium,_ are not entirely clear, though
some suggest it is of Thraco-[Illyrian](/wiki/Illyria "Illyria")
origin.[15][16] The founding myth of the city has it told that the settlement
was named after the leader of the Megarian colonists, Byzas. The later
Byzantines of Constantinople themselves would maintain that the city was named
in honour of two men, Byzas and Antes, though this was more likely just a play
on the word [Byzantion](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium").[17]

The city was briefly renamed _Augusta Antonina_ in the early 3rd century by
the Emperor [Septimius Severus](/wiki/Septimius_Severus "Septimius Severus")
(193–211), having razed the city to the ground in 196 AD for supporting a
[rival contender](/wiki/Pescennius_Niger "Pescennius Niger") in the [civil
war](/wiki/Year_of_the_Five_Emperors "Year of the Five Emperors") and rebuilt,
in honour of his son Antoninus, the later Emperor [Caracalla](/wiki/Caracalla
"Caracalla").[18][19] The name appears to have been quickly forgotten and
abandoned, and the city reverted to Byzantium/Byzantion after either the
assassination of Caracalla in 217 or, at the latest, the fall of the [Severan
dynasty](/wiki/Severan_dynasty "Severan dynasty") in 235.

### Names of
Constantinople[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Names of Constantinople")]

Main article: [Names of Constantinople](/wiki/Names_of_Constantinople "Names
of Constantinople")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG/220px-
Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG)](/wiki/File:Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG "Enlarge")

This huge [keystone](/wiki/Keystone_\(architecture\) "Keystone
\(architecture\)") found in [Çemberlitaş,
Fatih](/wiki/%C3%87emberlita%C5%9F,_Fatih "Çemberlitaş, Fatih") may have
belonged to a [triumphal arch](/wiki/Triumphal_arch "Triumphal arch") at the
[Forum of Constantine](/wiki/Forum_of_Constantine "Forum of Constantine"); the
forum was built by [Constantine I](/wiki/Constantine_I "Constantine I") in the
quarter of modern-day Çemberlitaş.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Column_of_Constantine%2C_July_2010.jpg/220px-
Column_of_Constantine%2C_July_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Column_of_Constantine,_July_2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Column_of_Constantine,_July_2010.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Column of Constantine](/wiki/Column_of_Constantine "Column of
Constantine"), built by [Constantine I](/wiki/Constantine_I "Constantine I")
in 330 AD to commemorate the establishment of Constantinople as the [new
capital](/wiki/New_Rome "New Rome") of the [Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire
"Roman Empire")

Byzantium took on the name of _Konstantinoupolis_ ("city of Constantine",
_Constantinople_) after its re-foundation under Roman emperor [Constantine
I](/wiki/Constantine_I "Constantine I"), who transferred the capital of the
[Roman Empire](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") from [Rome](/wiki/Rome
"Rome") to Byzantium in 330 AD and designated his new capital officially as
_[Nova Roma](/wiki/New_Rome "New Rome")_ (Νέα Ῥώμη) 'New Rome'. During this
time, the city was also called 'Second Rome', 'Eastern Rome', and _Roma
Constantinopolitana._[20] As the city became the sole remaining capital of the
Roman Empire after the fall of the West, and its wealth, population, and
influence grew, the city also came to have a multitude of nicknames.

As the largest and wealthiest city in Europe during the 4th–13th centuries and
a centre of culture and education of the Mediterranean basin, Constantinople
came to be known by prestigious titles such as _Basileuousa_ (Queen of Cities)
and _Megalopolis_ (the Great City) and was, in colloquial speech, commonly
referred to as just _Polis_ (η πόλη) 'the City' by Constantinopolitans and
provincial Byzantines alike.[21]

In the language of other peoples, Constantinople was referred to just as
reverently. The medieval Vikings, who had contacts with the empire through
their expansion in eastern Europe ([Varangians](/wiki/Varangians
"Varangians")) used the Old Norse name _Miklagarðr_ (from _mikill_ 'big' and
_garðr_ 'city'), and later _Miklagard_ and _Miklagarth_. In Arabic, the city
was sometimes called _Rūmiyyat al-kubra_ (Great City of the Romans) and in
Persian as _Takht-e Rum_ (Throne of the Romans).

In East and South Slavic languages, including in [medieval
Russia](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'"), Constantinople was referred to as
_[Tsargrad](/wiki/Tsargrad "Tsargrad")_ (_Царьград_) or _Carigrad,_ 'City of
the Caesar (Emperor)', from the Slavonic words _tsar_ ('Caesar' or 'King') and
_grad_ ('city'). This was presumably a [calque](/wiki/Calque "Calque") on a
Greek phrase such as Βασιλέως Πόλις _(Vasileos Polis),_ 'the city of the
emperor [king]'.

### Modern names of the
city[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Modern names of the city")]

The modern Turkish name for the city, _[İstanbul](/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul
"İstanbul")_ , derives from the [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language")
phrase _eis tin polin_ (εἰς τὴν πόλιν), meaning "into the city" or "to the
city".[22] This name was used in [Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish
language") alongside _Kostantiniyye_ , the more formal adaptation of the
original _Constantinople_ , during the period of
[Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") rule, while western languages
mostly continued to refer to the city as Constantinople until the early 20th
century. In 1928, [the Turkish alphabet was
changed](/wiki/Turkish_Language_Commission "Turkish Language Commission") from
Arabic script to Latin script. After that, as part of the 1920s
[Turkification](/wiki/Turkification "Turkification") movement, Turkey started
to urge other countries to use [Turkish names for Turkish
cities](/wiki/Geographical_name_changes_in_Turkey "Geographical name changes
in Turkey"), instead of other transliterations to Latin script that had been
used in the Ottoman times.[23][24][25][26] In time the city came to be known
as Istanbul and its variations in most world languages.

The name "Constantinople" is still used by members of the [Eastern Orthodox
Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") in the title
of one of their most important leaders, the Orthodox
[patriarch](/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical Patriarch
of Constantinople") based in the city, referred to as "His Most Divine All-
Holiness the Archbishop of Constantinople New Rome and Ecumenical Patriarch."
In Greece today, the city is still called Konstantinoúpolis/Konstantinoúpoli
(Κωνσταντινούπολη/Κωνσταντινούπολις) or simply just "the City" (Η Πόλη / Η
Πόλις).

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: History")]

### c. 657 BC–324 AD: Byzantium and earlier
settlements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: c. 657 BC–324 AD: Byzantium and earlier settlements")]

Main article: [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium "Byzantium")

Constantinople was founded by the [Roman Emperor](/wiki/Roman_Emperor "Roman
Emperor") [Constantine I](/wiki/Constantine_I "Constantine I") (272–337 AD) in
324[5] on the site of an already-existing city, [Byzantium](/wiki/Byzantium
"Byzantium"), which was settled in the early days of [Greek colonial
expansion](/wiki/Greek_colonies "Greek colonies"), in around 657 BC, by
colonists of the city-state of [Megara](/wiki/Megara "Megara"). This is the
first major settlement that would develop on the site of later Constantinople,
but the first known settlements was that of _Lygos_ , referred to in Pliny's
Natural Histories,[27] Apart from this, little is known about this initial
settlement, except that it was abandoned by the time the Megarian colonists
settled the site anew. The site, according to the founding myth of the city,
was abandoned by the time Greek settlers from the city-state of Megara founded
Byzantium (Greek: Βυζάντιον, Byzántion) in around 657 BC,[14] across from the
town of Chalcedon on the Asiatic side of the Bosphorus.

The city maintained independence as a city-state until it was annexed by
[Darius I](/wiki/Darius_I "Darius I") in 512 BC into the [Persian
Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire"), who saw the site as the
optimal location to construct a [pontoon bridge](/wiki/Pontoon_bridge "Pontoon
bridge") crossing into Europe as Byzantium was situated at the narrowest point
in the Bosphorus strait. Persian rule lasted until 478 BC when as part of the
Greek counterattack to the [Second Persian Invasion of
Greece](/wiki/Second_Persian_invasion_of_Greece "Second Persian invasion of
Greece"), a Greek army led by the Spartan general
[Pausanias](/wiki/Pausanias_\(general\) "Pausanias \(general\)") captured the
city which remained an independent, yet subordinate, city under the Athenians,
and later to the Spartans after 411 BC.[28] A farsighted treaty with the
emergent power of Rome in c.150 BC which stipulated tribute in exchange for
independent status allowed it to enter Roman rule unscathed.[29] This treaty
would pay dividends retrospectively as Byzantium would maintain this
independent status, and prosper under peace and stability in the [Pax
Romana](/wiki/Pax_Romana "Pax Romana"), for nearly three centuries until the
late 2nd century AD.[30]

Byzantium was never a major influential city-state like that of Athens,
Corinth, and Sparta, but the city enjoyed relative peace and steady growth as
a prosperous trading city lent by its remarkable position. The site lay
astride the land route from [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") to
[Asia](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and the [seaway](/wiki/Turkish_Straits "Turkish
Straits") from the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") to the
[Mediterranean](/wiki/Mediterranean "Mediterranean"), and had in the [Golden
Horn](/wiki/Golden_Horn "Golden Horn") an excellent and spacious harbour.
Already then, in Greek and early Roman times, Byzantium was famous for its
strategic geographic position that made it difficult to besiege and capture,
and its position at the crossroads of the Asiatic-European trade route over
land and as the gateway between the Mediterranean and Black Seas made it too
valuable a settlement to abandon, as Emperor [Septimius
Severus](/wiki/Septimius_Severus "Septimius Severus") later realized when he
razed the city to the ground for supporting [Pescennius
Niger](/wiki/Pescennius_Niger "Pescennius Niger")'s
[claimancy](/wiki/Year_of_the_Five_Emperors "Year of the Five Emperors").[31]
It was a move greatly criticized by the contemporary consul and historian
[Cassius Dio](/wiki/Cassius_Dio "Cassius Dio") who said that Severus had
destroyed "a strong Roman outpost and a base of operations against the
barbarians from Pontus and Asia".[32] He would later rebuild Byzantium towards
the end of his reign, in which it would be briefly renamed _Augusta Antonina_
, fortifying it with a new city wall in his name, the Severan Wall.

### 324–337: Foundation of
Constantinople[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 324–337: Foundation of Constantinople")]

representation of the city of Constantinople as tribute to an enthroned Mary
and Christ Child in this church mosaic. [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia
"Hagia Sophia"), c. 1000

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Constantinopolis_coin.jpg/220px-

[](/wiki/File:Constantinopolis_coin.jpg "Enlarge")

[Coin](/wiki/Coin "Coin") struck by Constantine I to commemorate the founding
of Constantinople

Constantine had altogether more colourful plans. Having restored the unity of
the Empire, and, being in the course of major governmental reforms as well as
of [sponsoring the consolidation of the Christian
church](/wiki/Constantine_I_and_Christianity "Constantine I and
Christianity"), he was well aware that Rome was an unsatisfactory capital.
Rome was too far from the frontiers, and hence from the armies and the
imperial courts, and it offered an undesirable playground for disaffected
politicians. Yet it had been the capital of the state for over a thousand
years, and it might have seemed unthinkable to suggest that the capital be
moved to a different location. Nevertheless, Constantine identified the site
of Byzantium as the right place: a place where an emperor could sit, readily
defended, with easy access to the [Danube](/wiki/Danube "Danube") or the
[Euphrates](/wiki/Euphrates "Euphrates") frontiers, his court supplied from
the rich gardens and sophisticated workshops of Roman Asia, his treasuries
filled by the wealthiest provinces of the Empire.

Constantinople was built over 6 years, and consecrated on 11 May 330.[5][33]
Constantine divided the expanded city, like Rome, into 14 regions, and
ornamented it with public works worthy of an imperial metropolis.[34] Yet, at
first, Constantine's new Rome did not have all the dignities of old Rome. It
possessed a [proconsul](/wiki/Proconsul "Proconsul"), rather than an [urban
prefect](/wiki/Urban_prefect "Urban prefect"). It had no
[praetors](/wiki/Praetors "Praetors"), [tribunes](/wiki/Tribunes "Tribunes"),
or [quaestors](/wiki/Quaestors "Quaestors"). Although it did have senators,
they held the title _clarus_ , not _[clarissimus](/wiki/Clarissimus
"Clarissimus")_ , like those of Rome. It also lacked the panoply of other
administrative offices regulating the food supply, police, statues, temples,
sewers, aqueducts, or other public works. The new programme of building was
carried out in great haste: columns, marbles, doors, and tiles were taken
wholesale from the temples of the empire and moved to the new city. In similar
fashion, many of the greatest works of Greek and Roman art were soon to be
seen in its squares and streets. The emperor stimulated private building by
promising householders gifts of land from the imperial estates in
[Asiana](/wiki/Diocese_of_Asia "Diocese of Asia") and
[Pontica](/wiki/Diocese_of_Pontus "Diocese of Pontus") and on 18 May 332 he
announced that, as in Rome, free distributions of food would be made to the
citizens. At the time, the amount is said to have been 80,000 rations a day,
doled out from 117 distribution points around the city.[35]

Constantine laid out a new square at the centre of old Byzantium, naming it
the [Augustaeum](/wiki/Augustaion "Augustaion"). The new senate-house (or
Curia) was housed in a basilica on the east side. On the south side of the
great square was erected the [Great
Palace](/wiki/Great_Palace_of_Constantinople "Great Palace of Constantinople")
of the Emperor with its imposing entrance, the [Chalke](/wiki/Chalke
"Chalke"), and its ceremonial suite known as the [Palace of
Daphne](/wiki/Daphne_Palace "Daphne Palace"). Nearby was the vast
[Hippodrome](/wiki/Hippodrome_of_Constantinople "Hippodrome of
Constantinople") for chariot-races, seating over 80,000 spectators, and the
famed [Baths of Zeuxippus](/wiki/Baths_of_Zeuxippus "Baths of Zeuxippus"). At
the western entrance to the Augustaeum was the [Milion](/wiki/Milion
"Milion"), a vaulted monument from which distances were measured across the
Eastern Roman Empire.

From the Augustaeum led a great street, the
[Mese](/wiki/Mese_\(Constantinople\) "Mese \(Constantinople\)") (Greek: Μέση
[Οδός] lit. "Middle [Street]"), lined with colonnades. As it descended the
First Hill of the city and climbed the Second Hill, it passed on the left the
[Praetorium](/wiki/Praetorium "Praetorium") or law-court. Then it passed
through the oval [Forum of Constantine](/wiki/Forum_of_Constantine "Forum of
Constantine") where there was a second Senate-house and a [high
column](/wiki/Column_of_Constantine "Column of Constantine") with a statue of
Constantine himself in the guise of [Helios](/wiki/Helios "Helios"), crowned
with a halo of seven rays and looking toward the rising sun. From there, the
Mese passed on and through the [Forum Tauri](/wiki/Forum_Tauri "Forum Tauri")
and then the [Forum Bovis](/wiki/Forum_Bovis "Forum Bovis"), and finally up
the Seventh Hill (or Xerolophus) and through to the Golden Gate in the
[Constantinian Wall](/wiki/Wall_of_Constantine_\(Constantinople\) "Wall of
Constantine \(Constantinople\)"). After the construction of the [Theodosian
Walls](/wiki/Theodosian_Walls "Theodosian Walls") in the early 5th century, it
was extended to the new [Golden Gate](/wiki/Golden_Gate_\(Constantinople\)
"Golden Gate \(Constantinople\)"), reaching a total length of seven [Roman
miles](/wiki/Roman_mile "Roman mile").[36]

### 337–529: Constantinople during the Migration
Period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 337–529: Constantinople during the Migration Period")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Theodosius_colum%2C_Istanbul.jpg/120px-
Theodosius_colum%2C_Istanbul.jpg)](/wiki/File:Theodosius_colum,_Istanbul.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Theodosius_colum,_Istanbul.jpg "Enlarge")

[Theodosius I](/wiki/Theodosius_I "Theodosius I") was the last [Roman
emperor](/wiki/Roman_emperor "Roman emperor") who ruled over an undivided
empire (detail from the Obelisk at the [Hippodrome of
Constantinople](/wiki/Hippodrome_of_Constantinople "Hippodrome of
Constantinople")).

The importance of Constantinople increased, but it was gradual. From the death
of Constantine in 337 to the accession of Theodosius I, emperors had been
resident only in the years 337-8, 347–51, 358–61, 368–69. Its status as a
capital was recognized by the appointment of the first known Urban Prefect of
the City Honoratus, who held office from 11 December 359 until 361. The urban
prefects had concurrent jurisdiction over three provinces each in the adjacent
dioceses of Thrace (in which the city was located), Pontus and Asia comparable
to the 100-mile extraordinary jurisdiction of the prefect of Rome. The emperor
[Valens](/wiki/Valens "Valens"), who hated the city and spent only one year
there, nevertheless built the Palace of [Hebdomon](/wiki/Hebdomon "Hebdomon")
on the shore of the [Propontis](/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara "Sea of Marmara") near
the [Golden Gate](/wiki/Golden_Gate_\(Constantinople\) "Golden Gate
\(Constantinople\)"), probably for use when reviewing troops. All the emperors
up to [Zeno](/wiki/Zeno_\(emperor\) "Zeno \(emperor\)") and
[Basiliscus](/wiki/Basiliscus "Basiliscus") were crowned and acclaimed at the
Hebdomon. [Theodosius I](/wiki/Theodosius_I "Theodosius I") founded the
[Church of John the Baptist](/wiki/Studion "Studion") to house the skull of
the saint (today preserved at the [Topkapı Palace](/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace
"Topkapı Palace")), put up a memorial pillar to himself in the Forum of
Taurus, and turned the ruined temple of [Aphrodite](/wiki/Aphrodite
"Aphrodite") into a coach house for the [Praetorian
Prefect](/wiki/Praetorian_prefecture_of_the_East "Praetorian prefecture of the
East"); [Arcadius](/wiki/Arcadius "Arcadius") built a new forum named after
himself on the Mese, near the walls of Constantine.

After the shock of the [Battle of Adrianople](/wiki/Battle_of_Adrianople
"Battle of Adrianople") in 378, in which the emperor [Valens](/wiki/Valens
"Valens") with the flower of the Roman armies was destroyed by the
[Visigoths](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths") within a few days' march, the city
looked to its defences, and in 413–414 [Theodosius II](/wiki/Theodosius_II
"Theodosius II") built the 18-metre (60-foot)-tall [triple-wall
fortifications](/wiki/Walls_of_Constantinople "Walls of Constantinople"),
which were not to be breached until the coming of gunpowder. Theodosius also
founded a [University](/wiki/University_of_Constantinople "University of
Constantinople") near the Forum of Taurus, on 27 February 425.

[Uldin](/wiki/Uldin "Uldin"), a prince of the [Huns](/wiki/Huns "Huns"),
appeared on the Danube about this time and advanced into Thrace, but he was
deserted by many of his followers, who joined with the Romans in driving their
king back north of the river. Subsequent to this, new walls were built to
defend the city and the fleet on the Danube improved.

After the [barbarians](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") overran the Western Roman
Empire, Constantinople became the indisputable capital city of the Roman
Empire. Emperors were no longer peripatetic between various court capitals and
palaces. They remained in their palace in the Great City and sent generals to
command their armies. The wealth of the eastern Mediterranean and western Asia
flowed into Constantinople.

### 527–565: Constantinople in the Age of
Justinian[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 527–565: Constantinople in the Age of Justinian")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Map_of_Constantinople_%281422%29_by_Florentine_cartographer_Cristoforo_Buondelmonte.jpg/120px-
Map_of_Constantinople_%281422%29_by_Florentine_cartographer_Cristoforo_Buondelmonte.jpg)](/wiki/File:Map_of_Constantinople_\(1422\)_by_Florentine_cartographer_Cristoforo_Buondelmonte.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_Constantinople_\(1422\)_by_Florentine_cartographer_Cristoforo_Buondelmonte.jpg
"Enlarge")

Map of Constantinople (1422) by Florentine cartographer [Cristoforo
Buondelmonti](/wiki/Cristoforo_Buondelmonti "Cristoforo Buondelmonti")[37] is
the oldest surviving map of the city, and the only one that predates the
Turkish conquest of the city in 1453

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Hagia_Sophia_Mars_2013.jpg/120px-
Hagia_Sophia_Mars_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hagia_Sophia_Mars_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hagia_Sophia_Mars_2013.jpg "Enlarge")

The current [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia") was commissioned
by Emperor [Justinian I](/wiki/Justinian_I "Justinian I") after the previous
one was destroyed in the [Nika riots](/wiki/Nika_riots "Nika riots") of 532.
It was converted into a mosque in 1453 when the Ottoman Empire commenced and
became a museum in 1935

The emperor [Justinian I](/wiki/Justinian_I "Justinian I") (527–565) was known
for his successes in war, for his legal reforms and for his public works. It
was from Constantinople that his expedition for the reconquest of the former
Diocese of Africa set sail on or about 21 June 533. Before their departure,
the ship of the commander [Belisarius](/wiki/Belisarius "Belisarius") was
anchored in front of the Imperial palace, and the Patriarch offered prayers
for the success of the enterprise. After the victory, in 534, the [Temple
treasure of Jerusalem](/wiki/Herod%27s_Temple "Herod's Temple"), looted by the
Romans in [70 AD](/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_\(70\) "Siege of Jerusalem \(70\)")
and taken to [Carthage](/wiki/Carthage "Carthage") by the
[Vandals](/wiki/Vandals "Vandals") after their sack of Rome in 455, was
brought to Constantinople and deposited for a time, perhaps in the [Church of
St. Polyeuctus](/wiki/Church_of_St._Polyeuctus "Church of St. Polyeuctus"),
before being returned to [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity
"Jerusalem in Christianity") in either the [Church of the
Resurrection](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre "Church of the Holy
Sepulchre") or the New Church.[38]

Chariot-racing had been important in Rome for centuries. In Constantinople,
the hippodrome became over time increasingly a place of political
significance. It was where (as a shadow of the popular elections of old Rome)
the people by acclamation showed their approval of a new emperor, and also
where they openly criticized the government, or clamoured for the removal of
unpopular ministers. In the time of Justinian, public order in Constantinople
became a critical political issue.

Throughout the late Roman and early Byzantine periods, Christianity was
resolving fundamental questions of identity, and the dispute between the
[orthodox](/wiki/Christian_orthodoxy "Christian orthodoxy") and the
[monophysites](/wiki/Monophysites "Monophysites") became the cause of serious
disorder, expressed through allegiance to the horse-racing parties of the
Blues and the Greens. The partisans of the Blues and the Greens were said[39]
to affect untrimmed facial hair, head hair shaved at the front and grown long
at the back, and wide-sleeved tunics tight at the wrist; and to form gangs to
engage in night-time muggings and street violence. At last these disorders
took the form of a major rebellion of 532, known as the ["Nika"
riots](/wiki/Nika_riots "Nika riots") (from the battle-cry of "Victory!" of
those involved).

Fires started by the Nika rioters consumed Constantine's basilica of Hagia
Sophia (Holy Wisdom), the city's principal church, which lay to the north of
the Augustaeum. Justinian commissioned [Anthemius of
Tralles](/wiki/Anthemius_of_Tralles "Anthemius of Tralles") and [Isidore of
Miletus](/wiki/Isidore_of_Miletus "Isidore of Miletus") to replace it with a
new and incomparable [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"). This
was the great cathedral of the Orthodox Church, whose dome was said to be held
aloft by God alone, and which was directly connected to the palace so that the
imperial family could attend services without passing through the streets.[40]
The dedication took place on 26 December 537 in the presence of the emperor,
who exclaimed, "O [Solomon](/wiki/Solomon%27s_Temple "Solomon's Temple"), I
have outdone thee!"[41] Hagia Sophia was served by 600 people including 80
priests, and cost 20,000 pounds of gold to build.[42]

Justinian also had Anthemius and Isidore demolish and replace the original
Church of the Holy Apostles built by Constantine with a [new
church](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Apostles "Church of the Holy Apostles") under
the same dedication. This was designed in the form of an equal-armed cross
with five domes, and ornamented with beautiful mosaics. This church was to
remain the burial place of the Emperors from Constantine himself until the
11th century. When the city fell to the Turks in 1453, the church was
demolished to make room for the tomb of [Mehmet II](/wiki/Mehmet_II "Mehmet
II") the Conqueror. Justinian was also concerned with other aspects of the
city's built environment, legislating against the abuse of laws prohibiting
building within 100 feet (30 m) of the sea front, in order to protect the
view.[43]

During Justinian I's reign, the city's population reached about 500,000
people.[44] However, the social fabric of Constantinople was also damaged by
the onset of the [Plague of Justinian](/wiki/Plague_of_Justinian "Plague of
Justinian") between 541–542 AD. It killed perhaps 40% of the city's
inhabitants.[45]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Walls_of_Constantinople.JPG/220px-
Walls_of_Constantinople.JPG)](/wiki/File:Walls_of_Constantinople.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Walls_of_Constantinople.JPG "Enlarge")

Restored section of the fortifications that protected Constantinople during
the [medieval period](/wiki/Medieval_period "Medieval period")

### Survival, 565–717: Constantinople during the Byzantine Dark
Ages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Survival, 565–717: Constantinople during the Byzantine Dark Ages")]

In the early 7th century, the [Avars](/wiki/Avars_\(Carpathians\) "Avars
\(Carpathians\)") and later the [Bulgars](/wiki/Bulgars "Bulgars") overwhelmed
much of the [Balkans](/wiki/Balkans "Balkans"), threatening Constantinople
with attack from the west. Simultaneously, the [Persian](/wiki/Persia
"Persia") [Sassanids](/wiki/Sassanid "Sassanid") overwhelmed the Prefecture of
the East and penetrated deep into [Anatolia](/wiki/Anatolia "Anatolia").
[Heraclius](/wiki/Heraclius "Heraclius"), son of the [exarch](/wiki/Exarch
"Exarch") of [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa"), set sail for the city and
assumed the purple. He found the military situation so dire that he is said to
have contemplated withdrawing the imperial capital to Carthage, but relented
after the people of Constantinople begged him to stay. The citizens lost their
right to free grain in 618 when Heraclius realised that the city could no
longer be supplied from Egypt as a result of the Persian wars: the population
fell substantially as a result.[46]

While the city withstood a [siege](/wiki/Siege_of_Constantinople_\(626\)
"Siege of Constantinople \(626\)") by the Sassanids and Avars in 626,
Heraclius campaigned deep into Persian territory and briefly restored the
_status quo_ in 628, when the Persians surrendered all their conquests.
However, further sieges followed the [Arab
conquests](/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Arab_Wars "Byzantine–Arab Wars"), first
from [674 to 678](/wiki/Siege_of_Constantinople_\(674%E2%80%93678\) "Siege of
Constantinople \(674–678\)") and then in [717 to
718](/wiki/Siege_of_Constantinople_\(717%E2%80%93718\) "Siege of
Constantinople \(717–718\)"). The [Theodosian Walls](/wiki/Theodosian_Walls
"Theodosian Walls") kept the city impregnable from the land, while a newly
discovered incendiary substance known as [Greek Fire](/wiki/Greek_Fire "Greek
Fire") allowed the [Byzantine navy](/wiki/Byzantine_navy "Byzantine navy") to
destroy the Arab fleets and keep the city supplied. In the second siege, the
second ruler of [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria"), [Khan
Tervel](/wiki/Tervel_of_Bulgaria "Tervel of Bulgaria"), rendered decisive
help. He was called _Saviour of Europe_.[47]

### 717–1025: Constantinople during the Macedonian
Renaissance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: 717–1025: Constantinople during the Macedonian Renaissance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Imperial_Gate_mosaic_in_Hagia_Sophia.jpg/220px-
Imperial_Gate_mosaic_in_Hagia_Sophia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Imperial_Gate_mosaic_in_Hagia_Sophia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Imperial_Gate_mosaic_in_Hagia_Sophia.jpg "Enlarge")

[Emperor Leo VI](/wiki/Emperor_Leo_VI "Emperor Leo VI") (886–912) adoring
[Jesus Christ](/wiki/Jesus_Christ "Jesus Christ"). [Mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic
"Mosaic") above the Imperial Gate in the [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia
"Hagia Sophia").

In the 730s [Leo III](/wiki/Leo_III_the_Isaurian "Leo III the Isaurian")
carried out extensive repairs of the Theodosian walls, which had been damaged
by frequent and violent attacks; this work was financed by a special tax on
all the subjects of the Empire.[48]

Theodora, widow of the Emperor [Theophilus](/wiki/Theophilos_\(emperor\)
"Theophilos \(emperor\)") (died 842), acted as regent during the minority of
her son [Michael III](/wiki/Michael_III "Michael III"), who was said to have
been introduced to dissolute habits by her brother Bardas. When Michael
assumed power in 856, he became known for excessive drunkenness, appeared in
the hippodrome as a charioteer and burlesqued the religious processions of the
clergy. He removed Theodora from the Great Palace to the Carian Palace and
later to the [monastery of Gastria](/wiki/Sancaktar_Hayrettin_Mosque
"Sancaktar Hayrettin Mosque"), but, after the death of Bardas, she was
released to live in the palace of St Mamas; she also had a rural residence at
the Anthemian Palace, where Michael was assassinated in 867.[49]

In 860, an [attack](/wiki/Rus%27%E2%80%93Byzantine_War_\(860\) "Rus'–Byzantine
War \(860\)") was made on the city by a new principality set up a few years
earlier at [Kiev](/wiki/Kiev "Kiev") by [Askold and Dir](/wiki/Askold_and_Dir
"Askold and Dir"), two [Varangian](/wiki/Varangian "Varangian") chiefs: Two
hundred small vessels passed through the Bosporus and plundered the
monasteries and other properties on the suburban [Prince's
Islands](/wiki/Prince%27s_Islands "Prince's Islands").
[Oryphas](/wiki/Niketas_Oryphas "Niketas Oryphas"), the admiral of the
Byzantine fleet, alerted the emperor Michael, who promptly put the invaders to
flight; but the suddenness and savagery of the onslaught made a deep
impression on the citizens.[50]

In 980, the emperor [Basil II](/wiki/Basil_II "Basil II") received an unusual
gift from Prince [Vladimir](/wiki/Vladimir_I_of_Kiev "Vladimir I of Kiev") of
Kiev: 6,000 [Varangian](/wiki/Varangian "Varangian") warriors, which Basil
formed into a new bodyguard known as the [Varangian
Guard](/wiki/Varangian_Guard "Varangian Guard"). They were known for their
ferocity, honour, and loyalty. It is said that, in 1038, they were dispersed
in winter quarters in the [Thracesian theme](/wiki/Thracesian_Theme
"Thracesian Theme") when one of their number attempted to violate a
countrywoman, but in the struggle she seized his sword and killed him; instead
of taking revenge, however, his comrades applauded her conduct, compensated
her with all his possessions, and exposed his body without burial as if he had
committed suicide.[51] However, following the death of an Emperor, they became
known also for plunder in the Imperial palaces.[52] Later in the 11th Century
the Varangian Guard became dominated by [Anglo-Saxons](/wiki/Anglo-Saxons
"Anglo-Saxons") who preferred this way of life to subjugation by the [new
Norman kings of England](/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England "Norman conquest of
England").[53]

The _[Book of the Eparch](/wiki/Book_of_the_Eparch "Book of the Eparch")_ ,
which dates to the 10th century, gives a detailed picture of the city's
commercial life and its organization at that time. The corporations in which
the tradesmen of Constantinople were organised were supervised by the Eparch,
who regulated such matters as production, prices, import, and export. Each
guild had its own monopoly, and tradesmen might not belong to more than one.
It is an impressive testament to the strength of tradition how little these
arrangements had changed since the office, then known by the Latin version of
its title, had been set up in 330 to mirror the urban prefecture of Rome.[54]

In the 9th and 10th centuries, Constantinople had a population of between
500,000 and 800,000.[55]

#### Iconoclast controversy in
Constantinople[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Iconoclast controversy in Constantinople")]

In the 8th and 9th centuries, the [iconoclast](/wiki/Byzantine_Iconoclasm
"Byzantine Iconoclasm") movement caused serious political unrest throughout
the Empire. The emperor [Leo III](/wiki/Leo_III_the_Isaurian "Leo III the
Isaurian") issued a decree in 726 against images, and ordered the destruction
of a statue of Christ over one of the doors of the Chalke, an act that was
fiercely resisted by the citizens.[56] [Constantine V](/wiki/Constantine_V
"Constantine V") convoked a [church council in 754](/wiki/Council_of_Hieria
"Council of Hieria"), which condemned the worship of images, after which many
treasures were broken, burned, or painted over with depictions of trees, birds
or animals: One source refers to the [church of the Holy
Virgin](/wiki/Church_of_St._Mary_of_Blachernae_\(Istanbul\) "Church of St.
Mary of Blachernae \(Istanbul\)") at [Blachernae](/wiki/Blachernae
"Blachernae") as having been transformed into a "fruit store and aviary".[57]
Following the death of her son [Leo IV](/wiki/Leo_IV_the_Khazar "Leo IV the
Khazar") in 780, the empress [Irene](/wiki/Irene_\(empress\) "Irene
\(empress\)") restored the veneration of images through the agency of the
[Second Council of Nicaea](/wiki/Second_Council_of_Nicaea "Second Council of
Nicaea") in 787.

The iconoclast controversy returned in the early 9th century, only to be
resolved once more in 843 during the regency of Empress
[Theodora](/wiki/Theodora_\(9th_century\) "Theodora \(9th century\)"), who
restored the icons. These controversies contributed to the deterioration of
relations between the [Western](/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism") and the
[Eastern](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church") Churches.

### 1025–1081: Constantinople after Basil
II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: 1025–1081: Constantinople after Basil II")]

In the late 11th century catastrophe struck with the unexpected and calamitous
defeat of the imperial armies at the [Battle of
Manzikert](/wiki/Battle_of_Manzikert "Battle of Manzikert") in Armenia in
1071. The Emperor [Romanus](/wiki/Romanos_IV "Romanos IV") Diogenes was
captured. The peace terms demanded by [Alp Arslan](/wiki/Alp_Arslan "Alp
Arslan"), sultan of the Seljuk Turks, were not excessive, and Romanus accepted
them. On his release, however, Romanus found that enemies had placed their own
candidate on the throne in his absence; he surrendered to them and suffered
death by torture, and the new ruler, [Michael VII](/wiki/Michael_VII "Michael
VII") Ducas, refused to honour the treaty. In response, the Turks began to
move into Anatolia in 1073. The collapse of the old defensive system meant
that they met no opposition, and the empire's resources were distracted and
squandered in a series of civil wars. Thousands of
[Turkoman](/wiki/Turkmen_people "Turkmen people") tribesmen crossed the
unguarded frontier and moved into Anatolia. By 1080, a huge area had been lost
to the Empire, and the Turks were within striking distance of Constantinople.

[Manuel I](/wiki/Manuel_I_Komnenos "Manuel I Komnenos"), c. 1180

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Istanbul_2009_Comnenus_Mosaics.JPG/220px-
Istanbul_2009_Comnenus_Mosaics.JPG)](/wiki/File:Istanbul_2009_Comnenus_Mosaics.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Istanbul_2009_Comnenus_Mosaics.JPG "Enlarge")

12th century [mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic "Mosaic") from the upper gallery of the
[Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"), Constantinople. Emperor
[John II](/wiki/John_II_Komnenos "John II Komnenos") (1118–1143) is shown on
the left, with the [Virgin Mary](/wiki/Mary,_Mother_of_Jesus "Mary, Mother of
Jesus") and infant [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") in the centre, and John's
consort [Empress Irene](/wiki/Piroska_of_Hungary "Piroska of Hungary") on the
right.

Under the Comnenian dynasty (1081–1185), Byzantium staged a remarkable
recovery. In 1090–91, the nomadic [Pechenegs](/wiki/Pechenegs "Pechenegs")
reached the walls of Constantinople, where Emperor Alexius I with the aid of
the [Kipchaks](/wiki/Kipchaks "Kipchaks") annihilated their army.[58] In
response to a call for aid from [Alexius](/wiki/Alexios_I_Komnenos "Alexios I
Komnenos"), the [First Crusade](/wiki/First_Crusade "First Crusade") assembled
at Constantinople in 1096, but declining to put itself under Byzantine command
set out for [Jerusalem](/wiki/Jerusalem "Jerusalem") on its own account.[59]
[John II](/wiki/John_II_Komnenos "John II Komnenos") built the monastery of
the Pantocrator (Almighty) with a hospital for the poor of 50 beds.[60]

With the restoration of firm central government, the empire became fabulously
wealthy. The population was rising (estimates for Constantinople in the 12th
century vary from some 100,000 to 500,000), and towns and cities across the
realm flourished. Meanwhile, the volume of money in circulation dramatically
increased. This was reflected in Constantinople by the construction of the
Blachernae palace, the creation of brilliant new works of art, and general
prosperity at this time: an increase in trade, made possible by the growth of
the Italian city-states, may have helped the growth of the economy. It is
certain that the [Venetians](/wiki/Venice "Venice") and others were active
traders in Constantinople, making a living out of shipping goods between the
Crusader Kingdoms of [Outremer](/wiki/Outremer "Outremer") and the West, while
also trading extensively with Byzantium and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"). The
Venetians had factories on the north side of the Golden Horn, and large
numbers of westerners were present in the city throughout the 12th century.
Toward the end of [Manuel I Komnenos](/wiki/Manuel_I_Komnenos "Manuel I
Komnenos")'s reign, the number of foreigners in the city reached about
60,000–80,000 people out of a total population of about 400,000 people.[61] In
1171, Constantinople also contained a small community of 2,500 Jews.[62] In
1182, all Latin (Western European) inhabitants of Constantinople [were
massacred](/wiki/Massacre_of_the_Latins "Massacre of the Latins").[63]

In artistic terms, the 12th century was a very productive period. There was a
revival in the [mosaic](/wiki/Mosaic "Mosaic") art, for example: Mosaics
became more realistic and vivid, with an increased emphasis on depicting
three-dimensional forms. There was an increased demand for art, with more
people having access to the necessary wealth to commission and pay for such
work. According to N.H. Baynes (_Byzantium, An Introduction to East Roman
Civilization_):

    "With its love of luxury and passion for colour, the art of this age delighted in the production of masterpieces that spread the fame of Byzantium throughout the whole of the Christian world. Beautiful silks from the workshops of Constantinople also portrayed in dazzling colour animals – lions, elephants, eagles, and griffins – confronting each other, or represented Emperors gorgeously arrayed on horseback or engaged in the chase."

    "From the tenth to the twelfth century Byzantium was the main source of inspiration for the West. By their style, arrangement, and iconography the mosaics of St. Mark's at Venice and of the cathedral at [Torcello](/wiki/Torcello "Torcello") clearly reveal their Byzantine origin. Similarly those of the [Palatine Chapel](/wiki/Cappella_Palatina "Cappella Palatina"), the [Martorana](/wiki/Martorana "Martorana") at [Palermo](/wiki/Palermo "Palermo"), and the [cathedral of Cefalù](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Cefal%C3%B9 "Cathedral of Cefalù"), together with the vast decoration of the cathedral at Monreale, demonstrate the influence of Byzantium on the [Norman](/wiki/Italo-Normans "Italo-Normans") Court of [Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily") in the twelfth century. Hispano-[Moorish](/wiki/Moorish "Moorish") art was unquestionably derived from the Byzantine. [Romanesque art](/wiki/Romanesque_art "Romanesque art") owes much to the East, from which it borrowed not only its decorative forms but the plan of some of its buildings, as is proved, for instance, by the domed churches of south-western France. Princes of [Kiev](/wiki/Kiev "Kiev"), [Venetian doges](/wiki/Doge_of_Venice "Doge of Venice"), abbots of [Monte Cassino](/wiki/Monte_Cassino "Monte Cassino"), merchants of [Amalfi](/wiki/Amalfi "Amalfi"), and the kings of Sicily all looked to Byzantium for artists or works of art. Such was the influence of Byzantine art in the twelfth century, that Russia, Venice, southern Italy and Sicily all virtually became provincial centres dedicated to its production."

### 1185–1261: Constantinople during the Imperial
Exile[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: 1185–1261: Constantinople during the Imperial Exile")]

Eug%C3%A8ne_Ferdinand_Victor_Delacroix_012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eug%C3%A8ne_Ferdinand_Victor_Delacroix_012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eug%C3%A8ne_Ferdinand_Victor_Delacroix_012.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Entry of the[Crusaders](/wiki/Crusade "Crusade") into Constantinople_, by
[Eugène Delacroix](/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Delacroix "Eugène Delacroix"), 1840.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Byzantium1204.png/220px-
Byzantium1204.png)](/wiki/File:Byzantium1204.png)

[](/wiki/File:Byzantium1204.png "Enlarge")

The [Latin Empire](/wiki/Latin_Empire "Latin Empire"), [Empire of
Nicaea](/wiki/Empire_of_Nicaea "Empire of Nicaea"), [Empire of
Trebizond](/wiki/Empire_of_Trebizond "Empire of Trebizond"), and the
[Despotate of Epirus](/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus "Despotate of Epirus"). The
borders are very uncertain

On 25 July 1197, Constantinople was struck by a [severe
fire](/wiki/Constantine_stilbes#Works "Constantine stilbes") which burned the
Latin Quarter and the area around the Gate of the Droungarios
([Turkish](/wiki/Turkish_language "Turkish language"): _Odun Kapısı_) on the
Golden Horn.[64][65] Nevertheless, the destruction wrought by the 1197 fire
paled in comparison with that brought by the Crusaders. In the course of a
plot between [Philip of Swabia](/wiki/Philip_of_Swabia "Philip of Swabia"),
[Boniface of Montferrat](/wiki/Boniface_of_Montferrat "Boniface of
Montferrat") and the [Doge of Venice](/wiki/Enrico_Dandolo "Enrico Dandolo"),
the [Fourth Crusade](/wiki/Fourth_Crusade "Fourth Crusade") was, despite papal
excommunication, diverted in 1203 against Constantinople, ostensibly promoting
the claims of Alexius, son of the deposed emperor Isaac. The reigning emperor
Alexius III had made no preparation. The Crusaders occupied
[Galata](/wiki/Galata "Galata"), broke the [defensive
chain](/wiki/Boom_\(navigational_barrier\) "Boom \(navigational barrier\)")
protecting the [Golden Horn](/wiki/Golden_Horn "Golden Horn") and entered the
harbour, where on 27 July they breached the sea walls: Alexius III fled. But
the new [Alexius IV](/wiki/Alexius_IV "Alexius IV") found the Treasury
inadequate, and was unable to make good the rewards he had promised to his
western allies. Tension between the citizens and the Latin soldiers increased.
In January 1204, the _[protovestiarius](/wiki/Protovestiarius
"Protovestiarius")_ Alexius Murzuphlus provoked a riot, it is presumed, to
intimidate Alexius IV, but whose only result was the destruction of the great
statue of Athena, the work of [Phidias](/wiki/Phidias "Phidias"), which stood
in the principal forum facing west.

In February, the people rose again: Alexius IV was imprisoned and executed,
and Murzuphlus took the purple as [Alexius V](/wiki/Alexius_V "Alexius V"). He
made some attempt to repair the walls and organise the citizenry, but there
had been no opportunity to bring in troops from the provinces and the guards
were demoralised by the revolution. An attack by the Crusaders on 6 April
failed, but a second from the Golden Horn on 12 April succeeded, and the
invaders poured in. Alexius V fled. The Senate met in Hagia Sophia and offered
the crown to Theodore Lascaris, who had married into the Angelid family, but
it was too late. He came out with the Patriarch to the [Golden
Milestone](/wiki/Milion "Milion") before the Great Palace and addressed the
Varangian Guard. Then the two of them slipped away with many of the nobility
and embarked for Asia. By the next day the Doge and the leading Franks were
installed in the Great Palace, and the city was given over to pillage for
three days.

[Sir Steven Runciman](/wiki/Sir_Steven_Runciman "Sir Steven Runciman"),
historian of the Crusades, wrote that the sack of Constantinople is
“unparalleled in history”.

> “For nine centuries,” he goes on, “the great city had been the capital of
> Christian civilisation. It was filled with works of art that had survived
> from ancient Greece and with the masterpieces of its own exquisite
> craftsmen. The Venetians ... seized treasures and carried them off to adorn
> ... their town. But the Frenchmen and Flemings were filled with a lust for
> destruction. They rushed in a howling mob down the streets and through the
> houses, snatching up everything that glittered and destroying whatever they
> could not carry, pausing only to murder or to rape, or to break open the
> wine-cellars ... . Neither monasteries nor churches nor libraries were
> spared. In Hagia Sophia itself, drunken soldiers could be seen tearing down
> the silken hangings and pulling the great silver
> [iconostasis](/wiki/Iconostasis "Iconostasis") to pieces, while sacred books
> and icons were trampled under foot. While they drank merrily from the altar-
> vessels a prostitute set herself on the Patriarch’s throne and began to sing
> a ribald French song. Nuns were ravished in their convents. Palaces and
> hovels alike were entered and wrecked. Wounded women and children lay dying
> in the streets. For three days the ghastly scenes ... continued, till the
> huge and beautiful city was a shambles. ... When ... order was restored, ...
> citizens were tortured to make them reveal the goods that they had contrived
> to hide.[66]

For the next half-century, Constantinople was the seat of the [Latin
Empire](/wiki/Latin_Empire "Latin Empire"). Under the rulers of the Latin
Empire, the city declined, both in population and the condition of its
buildings. Alice-Mary Talbot cites an estimated population for Constantinople
of 400,000 inhabitants; after the destruction wrought by the Crusaders on the
city, about one third were homeless, and numerous courtiers, nobility, and
higher clergy, followed various leading personages into exile. "As a result
Constantinople became seriously depopulated," Talbot concludes.[67]

The Latins took over at least 20 churches and 13 monasteries, most prominently
the Hagia Sophia, which became the cathedral of the Latin Patriarch of
Constantinople. It is to these that E.H. Swift attributed the construction of
a series of flying buttresses to shore up the walls of the church, which had
been weakened over the centuries by earthquake tremors.[68] However, this act
of maintenance is an exception: for the most part, the Latin occupiers were
too few to maintain all of the buildings, either secular and sacred, and many
became targets for vandalism or dismantling. Bronze and lead were removed from
the roofs of abandoned buildings and melted down and sold to provide money to
the chronically under-funded Empire for defense and to support the court; Deno
John Geanokoplos writes that "it may well be that a division is suggested
here: Latin laymen stripped secular buildings, ecclesiastics, the
churches."[69] Buildings were not the only targets of officials looking to
raise funds for the impoverished Latin Empire: the monumental sculptures which
adorned the Hippodrome and fora of the city were pulled down and melted for
coinage. "Among the masterpieces destroyed, writes Talbot, "were a Herakles
attributed to the fourth-century B.C. sculptor [Lysippos](/wiki/Lysippos
"Lysippos"), and monumental figures of Hera, Paris, and Helen."[70]

The Nicaean emperor [John III Vatatzes](/wiki/John_III_Vatatzes "John III
Vatatzes") reportedly saved several churches from being dismantled for their
valuable building materials; by sending money to the Latins "to buy them off"
(_exonesamenos_), he prevented the destruction of several churches.[71]
According to Talbot, these included the churches of Blachernae, Rouphinianai,
and St. Michael at Anaplous. He also granted funds for the restoration of the
[Church of the Holy Apostles](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Apostles "Church of the
Holy Apostles"), which had been seriously damaged in an earthquake.[70]

The Byzantine nobility scattered, many going to
[Nicaea](/wiki/Empire_of_Nicaea "Empire of Nicaea"), where Theodore Lascaris
set up an imperial court, or to [Epirus](/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus "Despotate
of Epirus"), where Theodore Angelus did the same; others fled to
[Trebizond](/wiki/Empire_of_Trebizond "Empire of Trebizond"), where one of the
Comneni had already with Georgian support established an independent seat of
empire.[72] Nicaea and Epirus both vied for the imperial title, and tried to
recover Constantinople. In 1261, Constantinople was
[captured](/wiki/Reconquest_of_Constantinople "Reconquest of Constantinople")
from its last Latin ruler, [Baldwin II](/wiki/Baldwin_II_of_Constantinople
"Baldwin II of Constantinople"), by the forces of the [Nicaean
emperor](/wiki/Nicaean_Empire "Nicaean Empire") [Michael VIII
Palaiologos](/wiki/Michael_VIII_Palaiologos "Michael VIII Palaiologos").

### 1261–1453: Palaiologan Era and the Fall of
Constantinople[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: 1261–1453: Palaiologan Era and the Fall of Constantinople")]

See also: [Byzantine Empire under the Palaiologos
dynasty](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire_under_the_Palaiologos_dynasty "Byzantine
Empire under the Palaiologos dynasty") and [Fall of
Constantinople](/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople "Fall of Constantinople")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Zonaro_GatesofConst.jpg/220px-
Zonaro_GatesofConst.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zonaro_GatesofConst.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Zonaro_GatesofConst.jpg "Enlarge")

Mehmed the Conqueror enters Constantinople, painting by [Fausto
Zonaro](/wiki/Fausto_Zonaro "Fausto Zonaro")

Although Constantinople was retaken by [Michael VIII
Palaiologos](/wiki/Michael_VIII_Palaiologos "Michael VIII Palaiologos"), the
Empire had lost many of its key economic resources, and struggled to survive.
The [palace of Blachernae](/wiki/Palace_of_Blachernae "Palace of Blachernae")
in the north-west of the city became the main Imperial residence, with the old
Great Palace on the shores of the [Bosporus](/wiki/Bosporus "Bosporus") going
into decline. When Michael VIII captured the city, its population was 35,000
people, but, by the end of his reign, he had succeeded in increasing the
population to about 70,000 people.[73] The Emperor achieved this by summoning
former residents who had fled the city when the crusaders captured it, and by
relocating Greeks from the recently reconquered
[Peloponnese](/wiki/Peloponnese "Peloponnese") to the capital.[74] In 1347,
the [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death") spread to
Constantinople.[75] In 1453, when the Ottoman Turks [captured the
city](/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople "Fall of Constantinople"), it contained
approximately 50,000 people.[76]

Constantinople was conquered by the Ottoman Empire on 29 May 1453. The
Ottomans were commanded by 22-year-old Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II. The conquest
of Constantinople followed a seven-week siege that had begun on 6 April 1453.

### 1453–1922: Ottoman
Kostantiniyye[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: 1453–1922: Ottoman Kostantiniyye")]

Main article: [Constantinople during the Ottoman
era](/wiki/Constantinople_during_the_Ottoman_era "Constantinople during the
Ottoman era")

The Christian Orthodox city of Constantinople was now under Ottoman control.
When [Mehmed II](/wiki/Mehmed_II "Mehmed II") finally entered Constantinople
through what is now known as the [Topkapi Gate](/wiki/Topkapi_Palace "Topkapi
Palace"), he immediately rode his horse to the [Hagia
Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"), where he ordered his soldiers to
stop hacking at the marbles and 'be satisfied with the booty and captives; as
for all the buildings, they belonged to him'.[77] He ordered that an
[imam](/wiki/Imam "Imam") meet him there in order to chant the
[adhan](/wiki/Adhan "Adhan") thus transforming the
[Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy "Eastern Orthodoxy") cathedral into a
Muslim [mosque](/wiki/Mosque "Mosque"),[77][78] solidifying
[Islamic](/wiki/Islam "Islam") rule in Constantinople.

Mehmed’s main concern with Constantinople had to do with rebuilding the city’s
defenses and population. Building projects were commenced immediately after
the conquest, which included the repair of the walls, construction of the
citadel, and building a new palace.[79] Mehmed issued orders across his empire
that Muslims, Christians, and Jews should resettle the city; he demanded that
five thousand households needed to be transferred to Constantinople by
September.[79] From all over the Islamic empire, prisoners of war and deported
people were sent to the city: these people were called "Sürgün" in Turkish
([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): σουργούνιδες).[10] Two
centuries later, Ottoman traveler [Evliya Çelebi](/wiki/Evliya_%C3%87elebi
"Evliya Çelebi") gave a list of groups introduced into the city with their
respective origins. Even today, many quarters of [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul
"Istanbul"), such as [Aksaray](/wiki/Aksaray,_Istanbul "Aksaray, Istanbul"),
[Çarşamba](/wiki/%C3%87ar%C5%9Famba,_Istanbul "Çarşamba, Istanbul"), bear the
names of the places of origin of their inhabitants.[10] However, many people
escaped again from the city, and there were several outbreaks of plague, so
that in 1459 Mehmet allowed the deported Greeks to come back to the city.[10]

## Importance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Importance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Istanbull_-
_palasset_-_13.jpg/220px-Istanbull_-
_palasset_-_13.jpg)](/wiki/File:Istanbull_-_palasset_-_13.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Istanbull_-_palasset_-_13.jpg "Enlarge")

_Eagle and Snake_ , 6th century mosaic flooring Constantinople, [Grand
Imperial Palace](/wiki/Great_Palace_of_Constantinople "Great Palace of
Constantinople").

### Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Culture")]

Constantinople was the largest and richest urban center in the Eastern
Mediterranean Sea during the late Eastern Roman Empire, mostly as a result of
its strategic position commanding the trade routes between the Aegean Sea and
the Black Sea. It would remain the capital of the eastern, Greek-speaking
empire for over a thousand years. At its peak, roughly corresponding to the
Middle Ages, it was the richest and largest European city, exerting a powerful
cultural pull and dominating economic life in the Mediterranean. Visitors and
merchants were especially struck by the beautiful monasteries and churches of
the city, in particular, [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"), or
the Church of Holy Wisdom: A Russian 14th-century traveler, Stephen of
Novgorod, wrote, "As for Hagia Sophia, the human mind can neither tell it nor
make description of it."

It was especially important for preserving in its libraries manuscripts of
Greek and Latin authors throughout a period when instability and disorder
caused their mass-destruction in western Europe and north Africa: On the
city's fall, thousands of these were brought by refugees to Italy, and played
a key part in stimulating the Renaissance, and the transition to the modern
world. The cumulative influence of the city on the west, over the many
centuries of its existence, is incalculable. In terms of technology, art and
culture, as well as sheer size, Constantinople was without parallel anywhere
in Europe for a thousand years.

[Armenians](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians"), [Syrians](/wiki/Syrians "Syrians"),
[Slavs](/wiki/Slavs "Slavs") and [Georgians](/wiki/Georgians "Georgians") were
part of the Byzantine social hierarchy.[80]

### International
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: International status")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Constantinople_imperial_district.png/220px-
Constantinople_imperial_district.png)](/wiki/File:Constantinople_imperial_district.png)

[](/wiki/File:Constantinople_imperial_district.png "Enlarge")

Constantinople's monumental center.

The city provided a defence for the eastern provinces of the old Roman Empire
against the barbarian invasions of the 5th century. The 18-meter-tall walls
built by [Theodosius II](/wiki/Theodosius_II "Theodosius II") were, in
essence, impregnable to the barbarians coming from south of the [Danube
river](/wiki/Danube_river "Danube river"), who found easier targets to the
west rather than the richer provinces to the east in Asia. From the 5th
century, the city was also protected by the [Anastasian
Wall](/wiki/Anastasian_Wall "Anastasian Wall"), a 60-kilometer chain of walls
across the [Thracian](/wiki/Thrace "Thrace") [peninsula](/wiki/Peninsula
"Peninsula"). Many
scholars[_[who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] argue that these sophisticated
fortifications allowed the east to develop relatively unmolested while
[Ancient Rome](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") and [the
west](/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire "Western Roman Empire") collapsed.

Constantinople's fame was such that [it was described](/wiki/Sino-
Roman_relations "Sino-Roman relations") even in contemporary [Chinese
histories](/wiki/Twenty-Four_Histories "Twenty-Four Histories"), the
_[Old](/wiki/Old_Book_of_Tang "Old Book of Tang")_ and _[New Book of
Tang](/wiki/New_Book_of_Tang "New Book of Tang")_ , which mentioned its
massive walls and gates as well as a purported [clepsydra](/wiki/Water_clock
"Water clock") mounted with a golden statue of a man.[81][82][83] The Chinese
histories even related how the city [had been
besieged](/wiki/Siege_of_Constantinople_\(674-678\) "Siege of Constantinople
\(674-678\)") in the 7th century by [Muawiyah I](/wiki/Muawiyah_I "Muawiyah
I") and how he exacted [tribute](/wiki/Tribute "Tribute") in a peace
settlement.[82][84]

###
Architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Architecture")]

Main article: [Byzantine architecture](/wiki/Byzantine_architecture "Byzantine
architecture")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Ayasofya-
Innenansicht.jpg/220px-Ayasofya-Innenansicht.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ayasofya-
Innenansicht.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ayasofya-Innenansicht.jpg "Enlarge")

Interior view of the [Hagia Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia"),
currently a museum.

The Byzantine Empire used Roman and Greek architectural models and styles to
create its own unique type of architecture. The influence of Byzantine
architecture and art can be seen in the copies taken from it throughout
Europe. Particular examples include [St Mark's
Basilica](/wiki/St_Mark%27s_Basilica "St Mark's Basilica") in Venice, the
basilicas of [Ravenna](/wiki/Ravenna "Ravenna"), and many churches throughout
the Slavic East. Also, alone in Europe until the 13th-century Italian
[florin](/wiki/Italian_coin_florin "Italian coin florin"), the Empire
continued to produce sound gold coinage, the [solidus](/wiki/Solidus_\(coin\)
"Solidus \(coin\)") of [Diocletian](/wiki/Diocletian "Diocletian") becoming
the [bezant](/wiki/Bezant "Bezant") prized throughout the Middle Ages. Its
[city walls](/wiki/Theodosian_Walls "Theodosian Walls") were much imitated
(for example, see [Caernarfon Castle](/wiki/Caernarfon_Castle "Caernarfon
Castle")) and its urban infrastructure was moreover a marvel throughout the
Middle Ages, keeping alive the art, skill and technical expertise of the Roman
Empire. In the Ottoman period Islamic architecture and symbolism were used.

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Religion")]

Constantine's foundation gave prestige to the Bishop of Constantinople, who
eventually came to be known as the [Ecumenical
Patriarch](/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical Patriarch
of Constantinople"), and made it a prime center of Christianity alongside
Rome. This contributed to cultural and theological differences between Eastern
and Western Christianity eventually leading to the [Great Schism](/wiki/East-
West_Schism "East-West Schism") that divided [Western
Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church") from
[Eastern Orthodoxy](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy "Eastern Orthodoxy") from 1054
onwards. Constantinople is also of great religious importance to
[Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam"), as the conquest of Constantinople is one of the
signs of the [End time in Islam](/wiki/Islamic_eschatology "Islamic
eschatology").

### Popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Constantinople&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Popular culture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Schedel_konstantinopel.jpg/220px-
Schedel_konstantinopel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Schedel_konstantinopel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Schedel_konstantinopel.jpg "Enlarge")

Page depicting Constantinople in the [Nuremberg
Chronicle](/wiki/Nuremberg_Chronicle "Nuremberg Chronicle") published in 1493,
forty years after the city's fall to the Muslims

  * Constantinople appears as a city of wondrous majesty, beauty, remoteness, and nostalgia in [William Butler Yeats](/wiki/William_Butler_Yeats "William Butler Yeats")' 1928 poem "[Sailing to Byzantium](/wiki/Sailing_to_Byzantium "Sailing to Byzantium")."
  * Constantinople, as seen under the Byzantine emperor [Theodosius II](/wiki/Theodosius_II "Theodosius II"), makes several on-screen appearances in the television miniseries "[Attila](/wiki/Attila_\(TV_miniseries\) "Attila \(TV miniseries\)")" as the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire.
  * Finnish author [Mika Waltari](/wiki/Mika_Waltari "Mika Waltari") wrote one of his most-acclaimed historical novels, _Johannes Angelos_ (published in English by name _"[The Dark Angel](/wiki/The_Dark_Angel_\(Waltari\) "The Dark Angel \(Waltari\)")"_) on the fall of Constantinople.
  * [Robert Graves](/wiki/Robert_Graves "Robert Graves"), author of _[I, Claudius](/wiki/I,_Claudius "I, Claudius"),_ also wrote _[Count Belisarius](/wiki/Count_Belisarius "Count Belisarius"),_ a historical novel about [Belisarius](/wiki/Belisarius "Belisarius"). Graves set much of the novel in the Constantinople of Justinian I.
  * Constantinople provides the setting of much of the action in [Umberto Eco](/wiki/Umberto_Eco "Umberto Eco")'s 2000 novel _[Baudolino](/wiki/Baudolino "Baudolino")._
  * The name Constantinople was made easy to spell thanks to a novelty song, "C-O-N-S-T-A-N-T-I-N-O-P-L-E," written by Harry Carlton and performed by Paul Whiteman and his Orchestra, in the 1920s.
  * Constantinople's change of name was the theme for a song made famous by [The Four Lads](/wiki/The_Four_Lads "The Four Lads") and later covered by [They Might Be Giants](/wiki/They_Might_Be_Giants "They Might Be Giants") and many others, titled "[Istanbul (Not Constantinople)](/wiki/Istanbul_\(Not_Constantinople\) "Istanbul \(Not Constantinople\)")."
  * "Constantinople" was one of the "big words" the Father knows toward the end of [Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss "Dr. Seuss")'s book, _[Hop on Pop](/wiki/Hop_on_Pop "Hop on Pop")._ (The other was Timbuktu.)
  * "Constantinople" was also the title of the opening edit of [The Residents](/wiki/The_Residents "The Residents")' [EP](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play") _[Duck Stab!](/wiki/Duck_Stab/Buster_%26_Glen "Duck Stab/Buster & Glen")_ , released in 1978.
  * [Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(band\) "Queen \(band\)")'s [Roger Meddows Taylor](/wiki/Roger_Meddows_Taylor "Roger Meddows Taylor") included the track "Interlude in Constantinople" on Side 2 of his debut album [Fun in Space](/wiki/Fun_in_Space "Fun in Space").
  * A Montreal-based folk/classical/fusion band calls itself "Constantinople."
  * Constantinople under Justinian is the scene of the book _A Flame in Byzantium_ ([ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number_\(identifier\) "International Standard Book Number \(identifier\)") [0-312-93026-7](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-312-93026-7 "Special:BookSources/0-312-93026-7")) by [Chelsea Quinn Yarbro](/wiki/Chelsea_Quinn_Yarbro "Chelsea Quinn Yarbro"), released in 1987.
  * "Constantinople" is the title of a song by [The Decemberists](/wiki/The_Decemberists "The Decemberists").
  * [Stephen Lawhead](/wiki/Stephen_Lawhead "Stephen Lawhead")'s novel _Byzantium_ (1996) is set in 9th-century Constantinople.
  * Folk Metal band [Turisas](/wiki/Turisas "Turisas") makes multiple references to Constantinople in their song "Miklagard Overture," referring to it as "Konstantinopolis," "Tsargrad," and "Miklagard."
  * Constantinople makes an appearance in the MMORPG game _[Silkroad](/wiki/Silkroad_Online "Silkroad Online")_ as a major capital, along with a major Chinese capital.
  * Constantinople makes an appearance in the "[Rome Total War](/wiki/Rome_Total_War "Rome Total War")" expansion "[Barbarian Invasion](/wiki/Rome_Total_War:_Barbarian_Invasion "Rome Total War: Barbarian Invasion")" belonging to the Eastern Roman Empire. It would reappear in the same role for the spiritual sequel, [Total War: Attila](/wiki/Total_War:_Attila "Total War: Attila").
  * Constantinople also makes an appearance in "[Medieval Total War](/wiki/Medieval_Total_War "Medieval Total War")." It is a starting province and city of the Byzantines.
  * Constantinople makes an appearance in the game "[Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings](/wiki/Age_of_Empires_II:_The_Age_of_Kings "Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings")" in the fifth scenario of the Barbarossa campaign and again in the third scenario of the Attila the Hun campaign in the expansion pack "[Age of Empires II: The Conquerors Expansion](/wiki/Age_of_Empires_II:_The_Conquerors_Expansion "Age of Empires II: The Conquerors Expansion")."
  * Constantinople is the main setting of the game "[Assassin's Creed: Revelations](/wiki/Assassin%27s_Creed:_Revelations "Assassin's Creed: Revelations")," the fourth major title in the best-selling "[Assassin's Creed](/wiki/Assassin%27s_Creed "Assassin's Creed")" series.[85]
  * Constantinople is also a setting of the Vampire: The Dark Ages role playing game by White Wolf.[86]
  * Constantinople is one of the territories featured in the [Board Game](/wiki/Board_Game "Board Game") [Diplomacy](/wiki/Diplomacy_\(game\) "Diplomacy \(game\)"). It is one of the default territories of Turkey.
